Comment: So you think Quintillion, a for-profit company, has hired Alcatel Lucent and is spending billions on the Arctic Fiber cable to bring internet to a few remote communities on Alaska's west and north coasts? Doubtful.

Arctic Fiber is a way to cut microseconds off of trading algorithms buy and sell times between Japan and European stock exchanges by using the most direct route possible by cutting across the Arctic Ocean. It's financed by banks and big financial trading firms, especially Cooper Investment Partners. Alaska happens to be on the way, and Quintillion in their wisdom have secured federal subsidies to run offshoots from the cable to connect these local communities... it is also good PR to do this, and the cable benefits by power injection at regular intervals as well. But the notion that Arctic Fiber is being installed solely for these communities is laughable.

So my fact-based comments seem asinine to you (meaning "stupid or foolish") -- how do you figure?

Comment: No doubt WWI was a foolish war that ended so badly WWII was bound to follow; the treaty was poorly done.

But there is a certain truth to the assertion that it made Canada a nation.  I agree with Ms Wente in that it is difficult to find nation building stories, since unlike most countries, Canada slowly evolved to nationhood.  We have no revolution to glorify, and we have never had conflict on our own soil except as a colony.  Illustrious tales are few, we slogged our way into nationhood, and the first seeds were sown not by us but by Britain in 1867.  WWI proved we could stand on our own.

As an aside, I am saddened by Wilson-Raybould 's remark that it is “hard to celebrate 150 years of colonialism.”  Aboriginals got a raw deal, true enough, but even though our history has its share of lamentable events, we have also done much to be proud of.  I can't think of a country I would rather live in.  If Mr Wilson-Raybould is ashamed of his country he has no business in cabinet.

Comment: Greedy Democrats....yea...since they've been in power for the last 10 years (not).

Also, a binary world is simple...us/them, dems/repubs....but not that helpful. 

President Washington warned of the danger of this binary partisanship: 

"A furious party spirit, when it rages in its full violence, exerts itself in civil war and bloodshed; and when it is under its greatest restraints, naturally breaks out in falsehood, detraction, calumny, and a partial administration of justice. In a word, it fills a nation with spleen and rancor, and extinguishes all the seeds of good nature, compassion and humanity.”

So let's all have a little less "spleen and rancor"!

We can always work for a more just, moral and enlightened government, but using party affiliation as a kind of racism...that's just not helpful. Judge the act for the act, the idea for the idea and be honest. 

As far as using the dividend...I think that's too regressive. Once again, the rich get richer and the poor get stepped on.

Anthropogenic global warming is a fact and it will have consequences, but these storms are *NOT* one of those consequences.

Despite what some might have you believe an increase in tropical storms is actually not one of the predicted outcomes of climate change.  If you read the UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change's (IPCC's) 5th report, which is generally taken to be the most complete current view on climate change, they discuss severe storms in Chapter 5 of their "Impacts, Adaptation, and Vulnerability" report, page 370, available here:

https://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg2/WGIIAR5-Chap5_FINAL.pdf

It is all of 2 paragraphs.  Why?  Because there really isn't much to say.  Their predictions:

- Globally tropical storms will decrease or stay the same
- Low confidence of an increase in wind speeds

That's it.  Out of thousands of pages, there are 2 paragraphs about storms.

Comment: Wind power does work, but it's very site-dependent. The power in wind is also a cube of the wind speed... and wind speed increases the higher you go. This is why turbines that work are tall (120'+ to get away from ground turbulence), and are sited in spots that have *constant* wind... ideally 7mph or more. I'm sure no one wanted 120' towers at this site, but that's really the way to get wind power... but even then, this site doesn't always have wind. Along Ediz Hook would be a better location (as long as turbines didn't interfere with approach to airport out there)

An option for this park site given its occasional wind could have been solar PV panels; 3kW of PV panels (about 12 panels) might have cost $15k and would be generating electricity already, because all commercial PV components are UL listed. The ROI on PV these days is maybe 10 years with minimal tax / production incentives, (5 to 7 years with incentives) and the maintenance is minimal... no moving parts!

Comment: I think the "bottle bill" is one of the best pieces of legislation ever passed. But I get the feeling Berteges isn't really being forthright. I just returned from Michigan and retailers still accept returnables at least in every store we went.  Also, I found it interesting that in big letters on each machine, the state lets you know it is a FELONY to return containers in Michigan that were purchased out of state.  In another letter on this same subject someone suggested that Oregon switch to returning containers by weight instead of individual containers.  Once my wife and I adjusted to the change in Hawaii, we found this very convenient since we had to return containers to recycling centers there.

Here's my point, while Oregon's bottle bill was a brilliant idea and legislation, it is now outdated.  There are a lot of things that can be improved to make it more fair (Who gets the money go?), easier to return containers, and increasing the types of containers that are returnable.

Comment: Nancy, you are really over-estimating the impact UH has on traffic.  Yes, when UH is out of session, traffic is quite a bit better, but UH is only one of a lot of schools for which the break in sessions overlaps; including HPU, HCC, KCC, LCC, all the private K-12 schools in town (Punahou, Iolani, Kam Schools), plus there are 180,000 public K-12 students many of which are also in town and generate traffic.

In fact, UH Manoa did a study a few years back and found that of the roughly 30,000 students, faculty and staff, nearly two-thirds lived within 2 miles of the campus and significantly more than half of the students do not drive to school already.

Furthermore, your argument ignores the fact the most students only go to the campus about 3 days per week for classes, and many students only have afternoon or night classes.  

The bottom line is that people think UH generates a lot of traffic, but this perception is simply not true and when actually look at the traffic details.

Comment: Actually higher corporate taxes mostly get passed onto employees of the corporation in the form of lower wages and to owners/shareholders in the form of smaller dividends or reduced capital.  The New York Times has a pretty good article explaining this here:

It should also be noted that lower employee wages and lower payment to shareholders both result in reduced personal income tax, partially if not completely offsetting any increase in corporate income tax.

Comment: Steve:  if you are going to opine, you owe it to your readers to describe the facts accurately.
1). There is another way to amend the Constitution that bypasses Congress.  Unlikely? Maybe.  But perhaps it would be more likely to succeed than going through Congress.
2).  Trump hasn't been elected by the Electoral College yet.  That won't happen until the 19th.  Don't get ahead of yourself.
3) The Constitution makes no provision for a popular vote for President.  If you don't believe me, I invite you to read the document for yourself. Article 2 Section 1 (as modified by the 12th Amendment) is a good place to start.  You will note the part about Electors being chosen by the state legislatures.   No popular election is required.  I'll bet that most who read this don't know this simple fact.  
Perhaps if more people would take an hour to actually read the document...and insist it be followed...we would all enjoy better governance.  What say you?

Comment: I worked for a company where my food and that of my colleagues was constantly disappearing.  The thief preferred yogurt.  No cup of yogurt was safe.  I worked for a manufacturing company at the time, where we used pharmaceutical grade dyes and aluminum lakes (water insoluble dyes).  We took a container of blueberry fruit on the bottom yogurt, removed the lid and the yogurt carefully, then added 5 grams of FD&C blue #2 aluminum lake.  We mixed it into the blueberries, and put the yogurt and lid back onto the cup.  We left it in the fridge in the break room overnight, and could then deduce who the thief was by seeing who missed the next couple days of work.  They would have had blue stains on their mouth and tongue that would have been impossible to remove.  They got the point though, and our food never disappeared again!

Comment: Good question.

A "submachine gun" is a fully automatic firearm, but is significantly different from an "assault rifle", in that it is designed to fire lower powered handgun ammunition (e.g. 9mm) instead of high powered rifle ammunition (e.g. 5.56mm or 7.62mm).  

This lower power allows for a smaller, lighter frame and barrel, making the weapon more portable and concealable, but at the expense of accuracy and range.

Examples of submachine guns include the H&K MP5, UZI, and the TEC-9.  Examples of assault rifles include the AK47, M16, and Tavor.

Any firearm capable of automatic fire (multiple rounds per trigger pull) is classified as a prohibited firearm in Canada.  Possession of a prohibited firearms without a license AND registration certificate is an indictable offence, punishable by up to 10 years imprisonment.

Comment: In Gallup polls since 1944 until before this election, only about 20% of the public has supported the current system of awarding all of a state's electoral votes to the presidential candidate who receives the most votes in each separate state (with about 70% opposed and about 10% undecided). 
	
Support for a national popular vote has been strong among Republicans, Democrats, and Independent voters, as well as every demographic group in every state surveyed.  In the 41 now shown on divisive maps as red, blue, and purple states surveyed, overall support has been in the 67-81% range -  in rural states, in small states, in Southern and border states, in big states, and in other states polled. 

In state polls of voters each with a second  question that specifically emphasized that their state's electoral votes would be awarded to the winner of the national popular vote in all 50 states, not necessarily their state's winner, there was only a 4-8% decrease of support.

Comment: From a strictly rational perspective, we do not know the details of what occurred, nor the future impact. We don't know whether or to what extent the girls will be traumatized, nor do we know what Craig's future will hold as a result of his conviction. 

Without that information, we cannot know if the sentence was too lenient or too harsh, so we look for a compromise that we think is consistent with the circumstances and probable outcomes. It isn't perfect, but that's how our criminal justice system works. 

As far as sex crimes are concerned, it is possible that lifelong registration for nonviolent first offenses (there is no evidence that he used force) is too severe a punishment, that it means the person can never fully recover. But, we have to balance that against the interests of potential future victims, so it is reasonable to err on the conservative side.

Comment: The fix needs to give the power back to the patient through patient spending.  Centralized, top-down, financing of health care makes the patient an expense.  And, the focus is then to manage the patient's access to healthcare to control expenses.  We have accomplished this through denying timely access to diagnostic services, surgical services, and closing beds.  If the patient brought the payment with them, whether through private insurance or through the use of the government health card, the focus in the system would be to facilitate access to bring in the payments.  I think we have learned that it is not feasible to finance a patient-focused system with taxes without underfunding every other government responsibility.  So, until private insurance is leveraged to help finance our healthcare system we will be relegated to long lines and tightly controlled access to care.

A friend of mine who worked for the US Embassy in Indonesia was inspecting an exporter of fish products to the US. The factory conditions he found were appalling and found boxes marked “JAPAN”. He shut down that exporter in a heartbeat, but not before he was offered a significant bribe not to do so. 

The same can be said for some of the terrible conditions of other seafood imported from China, Vietnam,Thailand and the Philippines which put US consumers at risk every day. Comment: Time Zones in Alaska were permanently changed in 1983. Prior to that the width of Alaska required five time zones to allow the Sun to be aligned somewhat with the noon hour.  Now we have just two time zones (Alaska and Aleutian/Hawaiian). We observe DST in only the Alaska Time Zone.  The effect of this can be seen during the period of DST when the Sun is highest in the sky at 2:00 PM in Anchorage and 3:00 PM in Nome.  

This change was done to placate Juneau who at that time was in the Pacific Time Zone with Seattle. Between them and the original Alaska Time Zone (Railbelt region)  was the Yukon Time Zone..  Anchorage was then two hours behind Juneau and that difference was used as a further justification to move the capital into the time zone where most of the states people and commerce were located. Bill Sheffield was behind this change and, as stated, the entire state (except the far Aleutians) were forced into a new Alaska Time Zone.  

Now can we just please stop changing clocks?

Comment: Alaska State Fish and Game allowed 40 bulls to be taken from the MaComb herd near Delta Junction. 31 were taken from Aug 5 to Friday, Aug 19. They are shutting down the caribou hunt for the McComb herd Sunday, Aug 21. It was supposed to last until Aug 27.  Over the last 3 years we have made about 15 trips back into this area going to our mine and prospecting. We saw a total of about 30 caribou and that includes trips into the coal mine. We saw a large hunting camp by Jensen's mine up on the hill and about 6 hunters last weekend. They were all carrying meat. I think this area is now over hunted and the 40 bull limit has pretty much devastated the herd in the area of Granite and McCumber Creeks.  This was supposed to have been a walk in hunt.  Every one we saw were on bicycles and one camp looked like it was set up before the season began using motorized ATV's.  Maybe they are bringing the meat out with motorized rigs too after Aug 25 when the walk in restriction is lifted.

Comment: That is done by following the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA), which is typically a 3-5 year process.
     * A group takes ownership and create a mtb trail design, construction and maintenance plans
     * An Environmental Impact Statements (EIS) and Environmental Assessments (EA) are created.
     * The plans are reviewed by Forestry Service ( hydrologists, fisheries and wildlife biologists, archaeologists, etc), other 
        interested parties, with lots of  public meetings.  Issues are identified and remediated.
     *  Once the plans are approved, then the trail can be built and maintained by the group, based upon the plan agreements.

We do not want a blanket permit.  We just want the ability to partner with land managers and others to decide what is in the best interest of each trail.  And it will allow trails that have already gone through this process, to still be used if the area is later designated as Wilderness.

Comment: I agree with your comments. In particular, the removal of former SCOTUS Chief Justice Taney was the absolute height of revisionist history.  In 1857, Taney penned the majority opinion (7-2) in the Dredd Scott case. The ruling is today assailed as one of the worst (long line mind you depending on your political views) cases by SCOTUS. 

At the time of the case, Taney was 80 years old. He was born in 1777 near present day Baltimore. He inherited slaves from his father's estate.  Several history sites noted that Taney manumitted or freed them. Taney was also the first Catholic to be appointed to SCOTUS.  Taney was a Democrat.  He was the U.S. Attorney General in Andrew Jackson's administration. 

160 years ago, an 80-year-old SCOTUS Chief Justice, born in the 18th Century, penned a majority opinion that was bad law. Today, his legacy is denigrated by Baltimore's Mayor and Civic leaders as just "another racist, male Caucasian" of history. History goes to the "victors".

Comment: I also have never had a gun pointed at me. I have been in a training environment wherein every single person, hundreds of them including children age 12 and older, were armed, much of the time with fully loaded handguns. I felt perfectly comfortable.
However, I understand your concern about every armed person making the right choice in the use of deadly force, especially those afflicted with mental/emotional, prejudicial, and disability issues. And yes, there are those who spoil for a fight and those who accept the invitation to fight.
In the gun culture circles in which I associate, our mantra is, the best gun fight is the one that never happened. Conflict avoidance and escape, if at all possible, is best. Only in the case of there being no escape, and wherein an attack is clearly imminent, the attacker has the means, the attack would likely result in serious injury or death, AND there has been no incitement on the part of the victim(s) is the use of deadly force lawful by civilians.

Comment: Allow me to inject some "history of Hawaii's infrastructure" at this point of the discussion. In 1954, the Territorial planners decided that they needed a "Mauka Arterial" to alleviate the mounting traffic on our roads. That was the start of what we know, today, as the H1 freeway. 

From that point in time, it took 35 years to build the entire route from Makakilo to Waialae, with the last bit being built in 1989. 

Now let's compare that to the rail. We were told that this (almost on a same scale of disruption) would take only 10 years to build. Well, guess what, as with the H1, the rail folks are learning some brutal truth, and that, in short, is that infrastructure projects on this scale is almost impossible to ram into a compressed timescale in Hawaii. 

The rail will be built - no doubt about it, but for the folks in town, Kakaako and UH - your train has just been delayed because the City tried to rush this project, with the results now showing up in today's hearing.

Comment: "...@John500AF - have you ever tried to refuse meds from your doc?..."

Absolutely.  Instances:  

Had terrible allergies back in the early 90's.  Went to the doc.  They did one of those pin prick tests.  Started taking shots.  Wasn't helping.  Talked to a friend who said it might be my diet.  Explained my diet...he suggested I quit dairy.  I did. Quit the shots. Haven't had allergies since. 

I had digestive issues and my doc wanted to put me on Prilosec for life (heartburn, what they called acid reflux).  They ran a bunch of tests and said I was just one of those people who would have issues.  Ran across an article that claimed if you didn't drink enough water, you might have digestive problems.  I checked my water intake and it was low, so I increased it. Fixed.

Doc wanted to put me on cholesterol lowering medicine.  Changed my diet (went full Paleo..no grain, no legumes).  Cholesterol is fine.

Doc won't even suggest prescriptions anymore 'cause he knows I don't buy into it.

Comment: I was in exactly the same position many years ago, running a smaller satellite company in Canada when our parent company in the USA was bought by a European conglomerate.  After stating that I would not move to Pittsburgh, I was told "If you stay for three months and wind down the Canadian operation you will get a good severance."  I had worked for the company for over 10 years.  As the closeout date approached, and I had nothing in writing, I started to push for the severance package and was told "You were offered a job in Pittsburgh", albeit a demotion since I was moving from the position of General Manager back to a project engineer, "so, if you don't take the job you get nothing but your two weeks vacation!"  Seemed like a good case of constructive dismissal to me, but was told I had to show damages, like being out of work for months.  Your best protection is to be a marketable commodity in the job market.

Comment: What local news reporting? Most city newspapers have laid off the majority of their reporters, and are filling their pages with wire service reports and using interns to shoot internet video content. Local TV broadcast news outlets send a guy to events to turn on a camera. Local radio, if they do any reporting is almost all commentary or one person stories about people grinding an axe.

Print and broadcast media coasted for decades, pretending that their total reach was the only thing advertisers needed to be concerned with and advertisers spent big time. Now that eyeballs aren't translating into ad clicks, the media outlets are no longer able to scam the scammers. Unfortunately in response they are cutting the reason they had readers and viewers to begin with.

If you want people to pay for content you have to produce something that isn't regurgitated opinion or wire service news. You need to find out and report on something people don't already know.

Comment: Perhaps 3 times, related corporations filed for reorganization.  I am not aware of any liquidations (Chap 7), or personal bankruptcies.  Commerce is a 3-spoked wheel.  One spoke is TAXABLE BUSINESS; another NONTAXABLE BUSINESS (charitable organizations); and another BANKRUPTCY.  All 3 comprise the Capital Market, each with its unique commercial dynamic.  Compare the separate powers of the Executive, Congress, and Judiciary wherein a power lawyer is master of all. Similarly, the best businessman will master all the spokes of commerce, which is rare.  While mere pedestrians deride the commerce of bankruptcy as hell, ironically, they would easily sink to hell in taxable commerce via incompetence in basic accounting and finance, and too, be even more lost in the maze of IRC sections 501 and 401, and ERISA 1974, as amended (the nonProfit venue).  Yet pedestrians commonly jump into value judgments concerning the bankruptcy venue.  I made that mistake once, but hope to never again.

Comment: Mr. Mickens,

Thank you for your feedback. Not everyone enjoys or supports everything our libraries do in our communities, but our hope is that among all that we do there is something for everyone. Most of what you note in your comments are things that public libraries across the country have been doing for many many decades. Help with homework, tutoring sessions, early childhood literacy...these are services that are important to many in our communities, and are a core part of our mission. (As a side note, we do provide early learning to all kids and families....there just wasn't enough space to mention everything we do.)

It is also important to mention that all of the above services and programs you mention are paid for through private funding for our Friends groups and the KCLS Foundation. And services such as tutoring are provided by volunteers. Public Libraries do a great job of helping coordinate community-wide efforts in this manner.

Best,
Gary Wasdin
KCLS Library Director

Comment: Do you know who loves a higher minimum wage? Amazon

Amazon's business model is such that they have very few minimum wage jobs as a percent of total workers, so a higher minimum wage does not have a big effect on them.

On the other hand, Amazon's competitors, the local mom and pop shops, are standard retail, and like fast food, retail has one of the highest proportions of minimum wage jobs. A higher minimum wage will therefore increase their costs dramatically.

So congratulations Wynne...you just gave giant corporations like Amazon an even further competitive advantage over the small mom and pop shops.

Comment: Most people aren't going to have more than one or two claims on their catastrophic major medical, if any, prior to turning 65 and going on Medicare.  So, it's cheap, and can be paid for out of your HSA.  And most people aren't going to spend their entire annual contribution in the HSA every year.  Many of us won't spend any of it.  And what we don't spend accumulates like an IRA.  If you suddenly drop dead of a heart attack, the money goes to your heirs, not the government, and not an insurance company.

We had set up one of these for our daughter so that she would never have to be tied to an employer for her insurance coverage.  But the ACA made it illegal.  That was a concern to me because when my first wife got pregnant with our 2nd child, I'd just changed jobs and the new coverage wasn't in effect yet, so she wasn't covered when she spent a month in intensive care back in the early 70's.  It took 2 years to pay those bills off.

Comment: There are additional costs under the current regime that we haven't yet addressed. 

For example, being convicted of possession, especially for the harder drugs, renders an individual less able to participate in society and the economy. (This is even more in the USA than it is in Canada, where a criminal record can deny you access to many jobs, most student loans, and so on.)

Anyway, considering the enormous cost of "crime/policing" under prohibition, we'd have to come up with a whole lot of new expenses under legalization to get back up to that level. So I don't think that increased costs are "quite conceivable" at all, frankly.

Costs are important, of course, but for me, the issue of justice is paramount. Where is the justice in convicting people for what's essentially a victimless crime? The job of the justice system is to protect people from OTHER people -- not from themselves. 

We should not be using the law to impose morality. That's unjust.

Comment: Actually, there's no evidence for your assumption that the complaints are "faulty" (whatever that means), especially when most sex assault victims don't make police complaints but many of them do report the crimes to sexual assault support groups instead.  

What has been proven is that the rate of unfounded cases vary substantially between different police departments due to the failure of some departments to investigate or even document complaints; and, we've also seen many cases now of judges being taken to task for not properly understanding sexual assault law resulting in retrial.

These new statistics point to more problems that can be addressed, one being that complainants should report the crime to police right away so they can gather all the evidence.  But of course that's not going to happen in jurisdictions where police are reluctant to even investigate complaints.

Comment: There were other reasons for ending the 1950s-type warehousing of mental patients.  They were, in fact, often badly treated.  Some of them were considered "crazy" for no reason other than that they'd been inside for so long nobody could imagine that it was just a mistake.  New drugs were becoming available which, it was thought, would allow outpatient management.  But the real clincher was, as always, money.  It cost a lot of public money to keep these people locked up.  The original idea was to put some of that money into community mental health centers to help these newly-released patients.  Why is it not surprising that the hospitals were closed and the community centers never opened?  The then-conservative state of California under its fearless Governor Rayguns led the way in this massive exercise in hypocrisy.

Comment: Millennials need to be managed and led, like any other staff. A large quantity of new ideas is great, but if the quality of new ideas is poor (i.e.: if the ideas are not relevant  or cannot be show to be relevant to corporate goals or strategy), they won't do you, your organization much good. One of the disconnects that I found with the millennials on my team was a 'shallowness' to many of the ideas - that initially, the proposals were very creative, but there was little thought given to benefits, costs, implementation, or follow-through. With some coaching, focus and direction, and a few personnel changes, the quality and usefulness of ideas have improved significantly. Also, there is now an understanding that not every idea can be pursued, that some ideas yield more than others, and that one 'good idea' does not immediately lead one to a corner office, and executive salary.

Comment: Of important qualities I thought a judge should have, their sexual orientation, religious beliefs (or lack of), political affiliation, gender or race were never a consideration for me or the other members of the Council I served with. 
As a public non-attorney member, I looked for honesty, professional and personal ethics, experience and knowledge in both civil and criminal law,  great work ethics, exhibited ability to meet deadlines and a real love of the law.
 Their temperament and humility was extremely important to me as well.
I paid attention to how people who had frequent contact with the applicant, non-attorneys (court clerks, members of juries, law enforcement, social workers, probation workers ) rated them. Was the applicant someone who treated all people, regardless of their status in life, with fairness and respect?  The legal profession already has an abundance of  practioners with over inflated ideas of their own importance without adding to it the power of a black robe.

The author of that biased report could well had written that Pebble may not harm salmon fisheries and been equally accurate.  But then that would not have served the authors misguided audience. Comment: "The Legislative Council may disagree with the Governor about the merits
of expanding Medicaid. The way for the legislature to exercise its constitutional
power to control the state's assets is through its constitutional power to pass laws."

"In conclusion, the court finds that the Social Security Act requires Medicaid
expansion. The court reaches this conclusion based on the plain meaning of
AS 47.07.020(a) and the canon of statutory interpretation that obligates courts to
construe remedial statutes liberally. Because the Social Security Act requires
expansion, state law makes the expansion group eligible for Medicaid services.
Because existing law required the Governor to provide Medicaid to the expansion
group, the Governor did not violate the Alaska Constitution by doing so."

http://courtrecords.alaska.gov/webdocs/media/docs/ak-leg-council/decision.pdf

Comment: Merlin's narrative struck a raw chord with me as we, too, lost a beloved and cherished soul earlier this year.

His description of his Homer matches our Scotchie-boy to a tee: a loving, comforting, spirit who brought a cathartic calmness to all of his "humans" whenever the weight of the day's trials and tribulations looked to overwhelm us.

Be it a dog or a cat or a bird or a fish or a horse or whatever ... a pet provides a reason for us to get up each morning for their walk, their feeding, their care.  They give us purpose. And in return nothing but total devotion and love.  All the while (usually unbeknown to us) they weave themselves into our very fiber.  And, absolutely, they look after us.

Only when they leave us do we come to understand that old saying: "you don't know how good you had it until it is gone."

I have endured the death of parents, aunts, uncles, cousins, close friends ... and the loss of my Scothie-boy has left a void no less deep and agonizing.

Good dog indeed.

Comment: He's not "reduced" to the lay state as if the lay state were lower than the clerical state. 

Instead, he is treated as if he were lay.  He's not permitted to say Mass, hear Confessions.

And similarly, he's not obligated to obey his bishop, say the breviary daily, remain celibate, etc. 

But in his soul he is still always a priest...it's just been decided that it's not in the Church's interest, the interest of other members of the Church, and even his own best interest to remain able to act as a priest.

Yet, beautifully and mercifully, if he were to run across someone in an accident who asked for a priest, he would be obligated to identify himself as a priest and to hear that person's confession, and if the conditions for absolution were met, to render absolution, just like he did before when he was first a priest. 

Isn't that beautiful?

Comment: Legally speaking, you're correct. But this is an issue that I think can't be adequately understood from a purely legal perspective. Citizens discussing this project is very unlikely to result in the project being stopped (or modified, unless the developer is unusually cooperative).

But it does serve a purpose. It lets the city, and developers, know that people care about their neighborhoods, and what issues are important to them when it comes to development. It has an effect on future planning and developer behavior. 

Complaining like these neighbors are doing is, as you point out, insufficient. Nonetheless, it remains untrue that the opinions of the neighbors just don't matter.

Comment: How pray tell would local truck farms address such catastropic occurrences?
.
War, either conventional or nuclear would disrupt shipments of petroleum products, spare parts and medicinal supplies.  Even if the local population would forgo drugs, meat, rice and other mainland sourced items it is doubtful that a subsistence diet of fruit and veg would long suffice. 
.
A tsunami sufficient enough to destroy Honolulu Harbor would also destroy the fisheries and most if not all of electrical generation and sewage treatment.  Absent power, fuel and basic sanitation the truck farmers would quite likely be unable to feed themselves, let alone a million plus residents and tourists. 
.
Finally shipping strikes occur regularly and have minimum impact on food imports.  If a work stoppage threatened public welfare the Labor Management Relations Act of 1947 better known as the Taft–Hartley Act would be invoked to break the strike.
.
The bottom line the Sustainable Hawaii Initiative is a farce.

Comment: It is my belief that no one should be discriminated against (let alone assaulted) on the basis of a characteristic which is irrelevant to the determination being made. So, for instance, skin color is irrelevant to whether someone is a good tenant, therefore nobody should be discriminated against in the case of housing on the basis of skin colour. The same goes, I would think, for how one dresses or the beliefs one has about the sort of thing one is. That being said, it is also my belief that a trans woman is not a woman (a trans man is not a man). That, so far I understand matters, is neither discriminatory nor hateful. By saying so, have I now opened myself to criminal charges or a human rights complaint under the newly-adopted law? If not, I have no beef with that law; if so, however, such a law illegitimately prescribes or sanctions beliefs and expressions of those beliefs, and I cannot but consider it fundamentally unjust.

Comment: Eric, I wasn't describing something that happens in the ocean, which is a different environment, or in the presence/absence of sunlight. If you don't want to believe me, how about the Encyclopedia Britannica?

https://www.britannica.com/topic/growing-season

"Growing season, also called Frost-free Season, period of the year during which growing conditions for indigenous vegetation and cultivated crops are most favourable. It usually becomes shorter as distance from the Equator increases. In equatorial and tropical regions the growing season ordinarily lasts all year, whereas in higher latitudes, e.g., the tundra, it may last as little as two months or less. Growing season also varies according to elevation above sea level, with higher elevations tending to have shorter growing seasons."

This definition completely contradicts your "length of day" theory.

Comment: Consumers are want the least expensive goods that can be provided. Businesses have to respond to that demand. It was demand for less expensive goods that caused the exodus of businesses to lowwer expense jurisdictions. Consumer goods produced in North America were more expensive and became, progressively, less competive with imported goods. Everybody wanted a flat-screen tv but they couldn't afford the domestic price but were more than happy to buy a less expensive one from Taiwan. Cheap goods sucked up good wages until good wages were sucked up by the inability to compete. The heyday is over and now the slow process of business repatriation must begin. Wages will have to be lower and domestic consumables will have to displace imports in order to foster the return. Given the dismal quality of most imported goods, there is an opportunity for repatriated businesses to regain domestic market share by offering better, more durable products if they can be produced at an acceptable premium.

Comment: To find out how cannabis use affects crash risk overall, in 2015 the U.S. government completed the largest case controlled study to date regarding DUI of cannabis and crash risk. [Compton and Berning. 2015]. It involved over 9,000 cases and controls spanning a 20-month period. It found that cannabis use while driving is not associated with increased crash risk once adjusted for confounding variables such as age, race, gender, and the presence of other drugs, including alcohol. Further, they found that cannabis did not add to the crash risk for drivers under the influence of alcohol. They did find that alcohol exponentially increased crash risk, double risk at 0.05% BrAC, 23 times risk at 0.20% BrAC. These results agree with an extensive 2013 review of 66 studies regarding crash risk and drug use which found that cannabis was associated with minor, but not statistically significant increased odds of injury or fatal accident. [Elvik R. 2013]

Comment: Yes it's true. The first time I used Amazon was last fall and I found the whole procedure astonishing; they made it practically idiot - proof.

Wow! Beat that Walmart.

In addition I visited my computer savvy friend in Seattle during April and before he took me on a tour of the Amazon warehouse area, which is beyond huge, he pointed to the neighbors across the street and said that they never visit a mall or store since they do all their shopping online, including groceries.

Comment: Oh I don't deny that there is some good to capitalism. It's undoubtedly had some good outcomes. But just as communism had evil outcomes despite good intentions, so capitalism has had good outcomes despite evil intentions.
The question of whether there were more good than evil is more subjective. I think there wasn't. Many think there was. But their insistence on citing as best outcomes of capitalism things for which the credit actually belong to endeavors independent of economics (such as scientific advances which have reduced world hunger) is strong evidence that the the real good outcomes are not all that impressive. Truly successful endeavors have no need to take credit for the achievements of others.

Capitalism works great as long as no business is ever allowed to get big enough that the owner is no longer part of and dependant on the community in which it operates. 
No businessman would dump toxins in his own drinking water. Nobody exploits their friends, family and neighbors.

Comment: Tax girl

Here are some history lessons for you.

China and India were the world's largest economies, from 1000 B.C. to 1850 A.D. Their empires were twice the size of the Roman Empire (I know you have probably been taught that the Romans had the greatest empire in the world. Not true. The Parthian Empire was their equal, and it was a second tier empire in Asia).

Second, every country faces a population explosion when its death rates fall (due to medical advances) but its birth rates remain the same. When Europe went through a population explosion, more than half its people emigrated to the Americas. Indians and Chinese have not been allowed to send half their population to the Americas.

Today, if everyone returned to their country of origin, then Ireland's population would go up by 500 percent. The UK would jump by 200 percent, Germany by 200 percent, etc. India would go up by 3 percent, and China would go p by 3 percent.

Comment: It remains a tragedy that as with every other major Canadian award, you must be alive to receive it. The Order of Canada is not awarded posthumously, thus depriving many "deserving" Canadians of their due. In 1935, my great grandfather, Benjamin Parks, and others created an organization called The Sociey for Crippled Cilivians. They raised funds by collecting donated furniture and clothing, and reselling them to raise money. He was the CEO from 1935 until 1972, and was under consideration for the Order of Canada. His passing meant that he could not be recognized for his legacy. Never heard of the Society before? You may know it better under its current banner - Goodwill. His son (my grandfather Ken) passed away two years ago, and I am sure was disappointed his father never received the recognition he so richly deserved. The United Nations thought him an exemplary human being, but owing to his death, Canada ignored his work.

Shame on you - to the Order of Canada and its archaic rules.

All the AHCA does is roll back Medicaid so that it no longer covers people who are middle-class (up to $55,000 in income for a family of four) and allow states to apply for a waiver so that insurance companies can price insurance to those with pre-existing conditions in line with what their medical condition is likely to cost to cover. Comment: Oregon funding works as you say, but the Eugene Education Fund (EEF) does not.  It goes where the people who donate it want it to go.  The more affluent the families there are in any given school, the more funding they have to spend on programs and additional FTE (teachers).  This leads to an embarrassment of riches at some schools with other schools getting by on the 10% hold back in grants that all schools can apply for.   Individual parents can do for the schools their children attend what we as a community are not allowed to do for our schools as a whole, namely pass funding levies to pay for additional programs and teachers.  Affluent schools get 90%, everyone else splits the 10%.  Does this sound like equity?

Comment: I am one of those 3000 investors.  Mr. Pape neglected to mention an important fact about the fees.  

There are reduced fees if you have a large holding and if you stay with the company for years.  He notes that the fee of the Founders Fund is 1.34%.  That is in the first $100K.  Amounts from $100K to $250K get a 20% reduction or a fee of 1.07%.  Amounts from $250K to $500K get 30% off (.94%) and over $500K get 40% off (.80%).

Furthermore, all accounts held by family members living at the same address are totaled for these calculations.  e.g. if you and your spouse each have $100 K, you get 20% off on $100K.

One more thing.   If you are a client for 5 years you get an additional 7% off, for 10 years 14%.

And the service is excellent.  If you call them, you get a person not a list of numbers to punch.  I have emailed and received a return phone call minutes later.

Comment: Djou's "bankrupt the city" statement is alarmist nonsense.

The ad narrator does not really say that the city housed more than 700 veterans.  She says WE have housed 747 veterans.  She does not say who "we" are.  The veterans have been housed using federal vouchers, many of which are administered by the state or others, rather than the city.  So although 747 veterans have been housed ON OAHU, it is FALSE for anyone to say that the CITY has housed those veterans.  Stating as fact that the city's claim "Is accurate," but that the city also "worked with federal agencies" is very misleading.  Someone needs to find out specifically how many federal vouchers the city has administered to house homeless veterans.  These bogus claims are deliberately made far too often.

Comment: Pope Francis says that only once did he overrule the CDF’s recommendation that an abuser priest be laicised. The problem is further down the line. Archbishop Coleridge of Brisbane told the Australian Royal Commission that he asked the CDF to laicise 6 priests who had been convicted by the civil law of child sex abuse offences. The CDF only agreed to laicised one. This makes a mockery of Francis’ claim that the Church has a zero tolerance policy. The Church has a zero tolerance policy for priests who have committed no crime but want to marry – they have to be laicised and not just have some restrictions on their public ministry. As Commissioner Atkinson of the Royal Commission pointed out, one of the most hurtful things for victims is to find that abuser priests are not dismissed even if their public ministry is restricted. Reporting to the civil authorities is the most significant problem with canon law, but the Church's disciplinary system also needs reform.

Comment: From the Oregonian: But Senate Minority Leader Ted Ferrioli, R-John Day, says it has already been rejected.
"The gross receipts tax is dead," he said in an interview Thursday. "It's a non-starter. It won't go anywhere."

In a nutshell, Hass says this is what the plan includes, though it's subject to change:
>> Repealing the state's corporate income tax
>> Enacting a gross receipts tax of .25 to .75 percent, possibly with different rates for different types of companies, on firms' Oregon sales over $1 million
>> Creating tax credits for business owners who pay their business taxes via the personal income tax, so their business income is not effectively taxed twice
>> Reducing the marginal rates for personal income taxes to help offset increased consumer prices caused by the gross receipts tax

Comment: There is a lot of info missing from this story. Predator control isn't an easy thing to accomplish, especially in Alaska. Most of this refuge is roadless an inaccessible . The hunting of wolves from airplanes and bounties are sometimes the only way to thin the population. It's not pretty, but it is the only way to effectively do it. There are not enough Fish and Game employees to do it . Bears do not travel in packs. They must be baited to draw them out. Bear populations get out of control quickly, like we are experiencing in Colorado right now. In northern Colorado there is an area where more bear and lion hunts were required to help the mule dear population. Death in nature is not pretty and this is not a Disney movie.

Comment: I would also say that, first impressions being important, a seller needs to realize that small flaws can become "invisible" over time to the person seeing them every day. However, a potential buyer can get an impression of a house being run-down, even if the flaws are strictly cosmetic and don't affect the structure or function of the home. Small things like scratched woodwork, grimy areas on paint or around doorknobs and switchplates, cobwebs in ceiling corners, sagging drapes and blinds, mineral-scale buildup around water fixtures, and wobbly hardware on kitchen cabinets can cause a potential buyer to decide to look elsewhere or make a low offer. It's easy for a homeowner to do the sprucing-up on these kinds of things, and can make a difference in the first impression that a buyer gets.

Comment: Precarious work is not a problem for those not yet affected  however it will increase as productivity through automation and globalization continues to grow.  

Who needs protection? The working poor who are now living with this problem; the millennials many of whom face difficulty in finding secure work; and established workers including managers and professionals some of whose jobs have already disappeared or are becoming precarious.

Corporate profits will increasingly come from developing economies as the buying power of workers in those countries slowly grows and the importance of revenue from developed economies will slowly decline unless entry to a domestic market is linked to a minimum content requirement.

The underwriting of corporate wages by taxpayers should be stopped through higher wages and benefits for those who need to also draw on social assistance to survive.

Distribution of wealth and the nature of work will have to be reconsidered as surplus labour grows.

Comment: I  Remember the Cold War years as a child.

Remember the Communist Witch Hunts of McCarthyism in America.
Remember the Rosenberg's being put to death.
Berlin airlift by American planes,dropping food and supplies into Berlin. 
Remember the Berlin Wall going up, people dying to escape.
Remember the Cuban/Russian Crisis discussed over the dinner table. 
Remember nightmares crying that the Russians were going to kill us. 
Remember the threats from the fat, portly grandfather Russian leader as he pounded his shoe.
Remember attending school with kids sent to America to escape Cuba. Leaving behind their parents, grandparents and homes. 
Remember the school drills we practiced climbing under our desks in case of a nuclear bomb attack. Remember weekends at home  spent gathering items for survival and rehearsals about what we were suppose to do, and where to go in the event of a bomb attack. 
Remember the American CIA pilot, Gary Powers, held captive in Russia. 

I remember praying for peace.

Comment: I went to work in labor relations for the State shortly after Steve Cowper said "All bets are off," and was on the front line of a two decade war thereafter.   The best thing you could do for the Alaska economy is shut down the newspapers and TV news.   Even as oil prices went from $30 and change to $10 and change, we only shed a few hundred State employees, and most of those were just constructive discharges of people we wanted to get rid of.   What crippled the State economy was fear.   The fundamental economy was sound; it wasn't growing, but it wasn't failing, but fear simply stopped consumption.   I was making a damned good living in the private sector in '85; in '86 I went to work for the federal gov't. because they got the money first; people just stopped buying.   Almost nobody had lost a job, the revenue stream was still sound, but the bad news just caused people to stop buying things.   This isn't going to be easy, but some of us have done it before.

Comment: @GIP Main, your post is taking some liberties with the truth too. 

First, a fraud was perpetrated by mortgage brokers independent of Home Capital who falsified applications in 2014 and prior years that Home Capital only learned of after the fact. A total of 45 brokers out of 4000 that marketed for Home Capital were suspended but the vast majority of mortgages underwritten for those brokers are sound.

Second, no "funding model" is diverse enough to prevent a run on the bank. Home Capital operates and complied with OSFI regulations, there is no suggestion that they violated those regulations which are some of the most conservative in the world.

Third, it has yet to be determined whether their non prime mortgage book (which is performing with below-average delinquency) will be going anywhere but if it does, it has value. High ratio mortgages are still covered by CMHC and even if the real estate market declines substantially, mortgagors take the loss long before the underwriters.

Comment: Sigh.

The bill does not 'make alleged discrimination a human rights abuse'  Any discrimination alleged has to be proven at a full legal hearing.

The Ontario Human Rights Commission does not hear cases.  The Tribunal does, and hears them according to legal standards (at risk of being overturned on Judicial Review)

The Tribunal itself does not 'punish', although it does award remedies.

Refusing to comply with a legal order of any court or Tribunal might possibly result in  contempt charges and eventually jail. On the exceptionally rare times when that happens, the trial takes place in a court on a criminal standard of proof beyond a reasonable doubt.

So no, you didn't understand it correctly.

But you can't buy them until 3 years later at that price.  Option plans may vary, but this is pretty standard.  If your company underperforms, and the price goes below $10, you're f**ked.

In reports, you got $100,000 in "pay", i.e. stock options.  But you actually have to buy it at that price.  Your gain is if the price rises above $10 per share, after buying them.

Joseph Ratzinger, "Conscience in Truth," in CRISIS OF CONSCIENCE, ed. John M. Haas [New York: Crossroad, 1996] p. 2.
